How Israel tracked down and assassinated scientists involved in Iran's nuclear program
subhead: Israel's attacks in June killed 16 leading researchers involved in Iran's efforts to develop an atomic bomb. Some of them had been under Israeli intelligence surveillance for two decades. With their deaths, Israel believes it has dealt the most decisive blow yet to Tehran's military nuclear program.
byline: By Louis Imbert, Ghazal Golshiri and Liselotte Mas

title: Macron calls for new era of Franco-British unity in address to UK Parliament
Texas floods: Over 160 people still listed as missing

title: In China, a 'black decade' for human rights lawyers
subhead: On July 9, 2015, Chinese authorities launched a sweeping crackdown on lawyers who dared to defend critics of the regime. 10 years later, the legal profession's room for maneuver has never been narrower.

title: Germany's federal government and royal family end a century-old dispute
subhead: An agreement has been reached regarding property confiscated from the Hohenzollern family: Items currently displayed in museums will remain there, while contested objects will be housed at a special foundation.

title: Spain's Costa Blanca bears the scars of a real estate frenzy
subhead: The region of Valencia in Spain suffered particularly from the real estate frenzy that led to the 2008 financial crisis. Between 2020 and 2021, the Basque photographer Markel Redondo explored this stretch of the Mediterranean coast, which is now rimmed with concrete. His photographs capture the scars that remain from a short-sighted vision of progress.

title: France will lend Bayeux Tapestry to the UK, Macron announces
subhead: While local authorities hailed the decision, conservators warned of the risks of moving such a fragile work across the Channel.

title: Channel crossings by migrants in small boats are on the rise
subhead: Since the beginning of the year, more than 20,000 men, women and children have managed to reach the United Kingdom – 7,000 more than during the same period in 2024. At least 15 people have died while attempting the crossing.
byline: By Julia Pascual (Boulogne-sur-Mer, Dunkirk and Loon-Plage special correspondent)

title: Tax on ultra-rich: 'France has the opportunity to lead the way,' say Nobel Prize-winning economists
subhead: As public deficits balloon and extreme wealth explode, creating a minimum tax on the assets of billionaires should be a priority, argue seven Nobel Prize-winning economists in an op-ed for Le Monde.
